DOC.HEAD: Terrorists Could `Increase the Carnage' Next Year, Officials Say
With AM-Judge-Explosion Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Terrorists pressing for more attention could well ``increase the carnage'' in attacks on airplanes and other targets next year, federal officials said Monday. One raised the possibility that chemical weapons will soon be used. Terrorist groups appear to be moving away from hijackings and toward airplane bombings, as evidenced by the Pan Am explosion last December and by the bombings this year of an Avianca plane over Colombia and a French UTA jetliner over Niger in Africa, said Anthony Wayne of the State Department's office on counter-terrorism. Thus, he said, the number of terrorist incidents might decline while the number of casualties would grow. In the first 10 months of the year, 410 people were killed in international terrorist attacks, according to preliminary figures compiled by the State Department. In the corresponding period last year, 308 people were killed. Terrorism has become so pervasive ``that it's lost much of its shock value,'' said Seth Cropsey, deputy assistant secretary of state for special operations. ``Terrorists, to stay on the front page and in the public eye feel they must increase the carnage,'' he said. As a result, ``it's likely that we'll see more efforts to bomb planes and the appearance of new weapons and tactics previously shunned by terrorist groups. Indeed, future concern is the possible introduction of biochemical agents,'' he said. Cropsey declined to elaborate on such prospects, citing intelligence sources. A third official, speaking on a seminar panel with the other two, cautioned against any expectation that reforms in the Soviet Union would result in a lessening of support for countries such as Cuba, Syria and Nicaragua that have been accused of financing terrorist groups. ``Until proven wrong, we should not operate'' on that assumption, said Oliver B. Revell, associate deputy director of investigations at the FBI. Revell, speaking at a George Washington University symposium on terrorism, said terrorist organizations such as the Marxist-oriented Japanese Red Army and the Palestine Liberation Front-General Command will continue to pose a threat to U.S. interests and to Americans in 1990. Investigations have focused on the PFLP-GC as a prime suspect in the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 over Scotland last December in which 270 people _ among them 200 Americans _ were killed. Revell also said ``a very small number of tightly disciplined'' Iranians among the 325,000 Iranians living in the United States could present a threat to Americans. ``Anti-U.S. sentiment has continued'' since the death of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini last summer, Revell said. Some 10,000 Iranian students on scholarships from their governments live in the United States and ``with this infrastructure, the threat appears to be substantial,'' he said. Tehran Radio reported in recent months on several meetings between senior Iranian officials and the leader of the PFLP-GC. In another development, a congressional report issued Monday said that increased security procedures since the bombing of Flight 103 are not being carried out properly at high-risk foreign airports due to a lack of training standards. The General Accounting Office report faulted the Federal Aviation Administration for not establishing minimum training requirements and standards for the extra security measures taken following the Dec. 21, 1988, disaster.
